news_summary: America’s largest offshore wind farm is set to become operational within six months, marking a significant advancement in clean energy development.

articles.title: America’s biggest offshore wind farm will be online in 6 months
articles.content:
About 30 miles off the coast of Virginia Beach, Virginia, workers have been building America’s largest offshore wind farm at a breakneck pace. The project will start feeding power to the grid by March — the most definitive start date provided by its developer yet.

“First power will occur in Q1 of next year,” Dominion Energy spokesperson Jeremy Slayton told Canary Media. ​“And we are still on schedule to complete by late 2026.”

In an August earnings call, Dominion Energy CEO Robert Blue provided a vague window of ​“early 2026” when asked when the 2.6-gigawatt Coastal Virginia Offshore Wind, or CVOW, project would start generating renewable power for the energy-hungry state.

As of the end of September, Dominion had installed all 176 turbine foundations — ​“a big, important milestone,” per Slayton. That accomplishment involved pile-driving 98 foundations into the soft seabed during the five-month stretch when such work is permitted. Good weather helped the work move along quickly, as did the Atlantic Ocean’s unusually quiet hurricane season.

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

Speed is key when building wind projects under the eye of a president who has called turbines ​​“ugly” and ​​“terrible for tourism” — and who has followed up with attempts to dismantle the industry.

Had CVOW not finished foundation installation by the end of this month, turbine construction would have been delayed until next spring. Federal permitting restricts pile-driving to a May-through-October window to protect migrating North Atlantic right whales. Such a delay would have made CVOW more vulnerable to the wrath of the Trump administration, which has already issued stop-work orders to two offshore wind farms under construction.

Charybdis, an American-made wind-turbine-installation ship, arrived at Portsmouth Marine Terminal in Virginia on September 17. Dominion Energy

But Slayton said the threat of President Donald Trump’s interference doesn’t concern him. CVOW is, after all, 1 of only 2 in-progress offshore wind projects that hasn’t been directly attacked by the president.

“Our project has enjoyed bipartisan support from the beginning,” he said, pointing to backing from some of the state’s leading Republicans, including Governor Glenn Youngkin and U.S. Representative Jen Kiggans.

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

Kiggans, who represents the politically moderate Virginia Beach area, brought her concerns about Trump’s escalating war on wind to the House floor last month, when Congress returned from recess. She called CVOW ​“important to Virginia,” and House Speaker Mike Johnson, a Republican from Louisiana, later told reporters that he relayed Kiggans’ message directly to Trump.

“I understand the priority for Virginians and we want to do right by them, so we’ll see,” Johnson told Politico​’s E&E News, in a comment that broke from an anti–offshore wind narrative that’s taken root among many of his fellow House Republicans.

The project is crucial for helping the state meet a deluge of new electricity demand, as Virginia is at the center of the nationwide boom in data-center construction. CVOW will provide a huge amount of carbon-free power to the state and Dominion, its largest utility — helping both keep pace with rising demand without having to burn more polluting fossil fuels.

Kiggans also tied the success of CVOW to the needs of Virginia’s military installations.

“I always speak about that project in light of the national security benefit and that benefit to Naval Air Station Oceana,” Kiggans said last month in an interview with WAVY, a Virginia news station, noting that a partnership with Dominion is ​“giving Naval Air Station Oceana a $500 million power grid upgrade.”

Dominion has already spent $6 billion on the monumental effort to build CVOW, which has been 12 years in the making. Almost $1 billion of that investment has flowed to the local economy, creating 802 full- and part-time jobs in the state’s Hampton Roads region, according to G.T. Hollett, Dominion Energy’s director of offshore wind.

CVOW’s benefits are being felt nationwide too.

“The project has already created 2,000 direct and indirect American jobs and generated $2 billion in economic activity, strengthening the nation’s manufacturing supply chains and our regional economy,” said Katharine Kollins, president of Southeastern Wind Coalition.

Now Dominion will turn to the final phase of construction: turbine installation. The work is made possible by Charybdis — the first U.S.-built, Jones Act–compliant wind-turbine installation vessel — which arrived in Virginia’s Portsmouth Marine Terminal last month.

“When Charybdis is loaded up, it will have all the components to install four turbines with each trip,” said Slayton, who noted that the pace of the build is well timed given Virginia’s data center boom. The state is facing ​“record growth and energy demand … maybe you’ve heard.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the imminent completion and operation of America's largest offshore wind farm, which will provide significant renewable energy, reduce carbon emissions, create thousands of jobs, and support local and national economies. It highlights broad environmental and economic benefits with detailed context about the project's scale, bipartisan support, and its importance for meeting rising energy demands sustainably.
articles.personality_title: America’s largest offshore wind farm to start producing power in six months
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Off the coast of Virginia Beach, Virginia, workers are building America’s biggest offshore wind farm. This project aims to produce a large amount of clean energy to meet the state’s growing power needs.

**What happened** – Dominion Energy announced that the Coastal Virginia Offshore Wind (CVOW) farm will begin sending electricity to the grid by March next year. All 176 turbine foundations have been installed on time, thanks to good weather and careful planning to protect whales. The special American-built ship Charybdis arrived recently to help install the turbines.

**Impact** – This wind farm will generate 2.6 gigawatts of carbon-free power, enough to support Virginia’s booming data centers and military bases. The project has created 2,000 jobs and brought $2 billion in economic activity to the region. It also shows strong support from both political parties, which is rare for such large energy projects.

**What's next step** – The next phase is installing the wind turbines using the ship Charybdis. Once finished, the farm will help Virginia meet its rising electricity demand with clean energy, reducing the need for fossil fuels.

**One-sentence takeaway** – America’s largest offshore wind farm is on track to supply clean energy and boost local jobs, marking a major step in Virginia’s energy future.
articles.personality_title_fr: La plus grande ferme éolienne offshore américaine commencera à produire de l'électricité dans six mois
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Au large de Virginia Beach, en Virginie, des ouvriers construisent la plus grande ferme éolienne offshore des États-Unis. Ce projet vise à produire une grande quantité d’énergie propre pour répondre aux besoins croissants de l’État.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Dominion Energy a annoncé que la ferme éolienne Coastal Virginia Offshore Wind (CVOW) commencera à fournir de l’électricité au réseau en mars prochain. Toutes les 176 fondations des turbines ont été installées à temps, grâce à une météo favorable et à une planification pour protéger les baleines. Le navire américain Charybdis est arrivé récemment pour aider à installer les turbines.

**Impact** – Cette ferme produira 2,6 gigawatts d’énergie sans carbone, suffisante pour soutenir la croissance des centres de données et des bases militaires en Virginie. Le projet a créé 2 000 emplois et généré 2 milliards de dollars d’activité économique dans la région. Il bénéficie aussi d’un large soutien politique, ce qui est rare pour un projet énergétique d’une telle envergure.

**Prochaine étape** – La phase suivante consiste à installer les turbines à l’aide du navire Charybdis. Une fois terminée, la ferme aidera la Virginie à répondre à la demande croissante d’électricité avec une énergie propre, réduisant le recours aux combustibles fossiles.

**Une phrase clé** – La plus grande ferme éolienne offshore américaine est en bonne voie pour fournir de l’énergie propre et créer des emplois locaux, marquant une étape importante pour l’avenir énergétique de la Virginie.
articles.personality_title_es: La mayor planta eólica marina de Estados Unidos comenzará a producir energía en seis meses
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – A unos 30 millas de la costa de Virginia Beach, Virginia, trabajadores están construyendo la planta eólica marina más grande de Estados Unidos. Este proyecto busca generar mucha energía limpia para cubrir la creciente demanda del estado.

**Qué pasó** – Dominion Energy anunció que el parque eólico Coastal Virginia Offshore Wind (CVOW) comenzará a enviar electricidad a la red en marzo del próximo año. Se han instalado todas las 176 bases para las turbinas a tiempo, gracias al buen clima y a medidas para proteger a las ballenas. El barco estadounidense Charybdis llegó recientemente para ayudar a instalar las turbinas.

**Impacto** – Esta planta generará 2,6 gigavatios de energía sin carbono, suficiente para apoyar el crecimiento de centros de datos y bases militares en Virginia. El proyecto ha creado 2,000 empleos y generado 2,000 millones de dólares en actividad económica para la región. Además, cuenta con un fuerte apoyo político de ambos partidos.

**Próximo paso** – La siguiente fase es instalar las turbinas usando el barco Charybdis. Cuando termine, la planta ayudará a Virginia a satisfacer la creciente demanda eléctrica con energía limpia, reduciendo la necesidad de combustibles fósiles.

**Una frase clave** – La mayor planta eólica marina de Estados Unidos está lista para suministrar energía limpia y crear empleos locales, marcando un avance importante en el futuro energético de Virginia.
